alert.note: Alert for Brown; Calumet; Door; Florence; Forest; Kewaunee; Langlade; Lincoln; Manitowoc; Marathon; Menominee; Northern Marinette County; Northern Oconto County; Oneida; Outagamie; Portage; Shawano; Southern Marinette County; Southern Oconto County; Vilas; Waupaca; Waushara; Winnebago; Wood (Wisconsin) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GreenBay (East Central Wisconsin - Green Bay)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 10 at 11:30AM CST by NWS GreenBay
info.description: ...SNOW EXPECTED TO RESULT IN HAZARDOUS TRAVEL CONDITIONS THIS EVENING... A fast moving storm system will drop southeast from Canada today, reaching northwest Minnesota by early evening, and then western Lake Superior by midnight. Snow generated by the storm will push into central and north-central Wisconsin during the late afternoon hours, and then spread into eastern Wisconsin during the early evening. The main snow band with the storm will push through the area quickly during the evening, resulting in a few hours of fairly heavy snowfall. The fast movement of the snow band will cause travel conditions to deteriorate rapidly once the snow begins. Gusty south winds occurring at the same time may also generate some drifting snow, which will add to the travel difficulty. Anyone planning travel during the evening hours should expect to encounter hazardous road conditions, and allow extra time to reach their destination. The precipitation will taper off to occasional light snow and freezing drizzle later in the night, once the main snow band shifts east of the area. Temperatures may even warm enough to allow the freezing drizzle to change to drizzle across portions of central and east-central Wisconsin late tonight. After a relatively mild start to the day Friday, colder air will begin to surge back across the area. Temperatures are expected to fall quickly late Friday afternoon and Friday evening. That may allow lingering water or slush to re-freeze on the roads, resulting in some icy spots.
